title: Where is My Mind? (Cover Song)
text: I do a vocal + piano laid back version at shows. However, Iâ€™ve changed up my setup so Iâ€™ve decided to do a solo piano version. First heard it at the end of Fight Club like everyone else â€” how vanilla am I?

title: Where is My Mind? (Cover Song)
text: I do a vocal + piano laid back version at shows. However, Iâ€™ve changed up my setup so Iâ€™ve decided to do a solo piano version. First heard it at the end of Fight Club like everyone else â€” how vanilla am I?

title: Sweetwater â€“ A 3D Player Piano
text:
This is an arrangement I made featuring four voices. I originally got the idea from the player piano from the Westworld intro, but I wanted to expand on it â€” having it move through space on three axes. To make things even more compelling I wanted a time-synced effect with each voice.


After I recorded the performance on a green screen and 4K camera, I used After Effects, Visual Studio Code + Adobe plugin, and Tone.js to render the MIDI data. The mixing was done in Ableton.



Green screen and Seaboard RISE 25

title: Sweetwater â€“ A 3D Player Piano
text:
This is an arrangement I made featuring four voices. I originally got the idea from the player piano from the Westworld intro, but I wanted to expand on it â€” having it move through space on three axes. To make things even more compelling I wanted a time-synced effect with each voice.


After I recorded the performance on a green screen and 4K camera, I used After Effects, Visual Studio Code + Adobe plugin, and Tone.js to render the MIDI data. The mixing was done in Ableton.



Green screen and Seaboard RISE 25

title: Sweetwater â€“ A 3D Player Piano
text:
Products and Libraries

ROLI Seaboard RISE 25

Tone.js

Types for Adobe

Visual Studio Code

Node.js

Adobe After Effects

ExtendScript Debugger for VSCode

I also used Premiere/Media Encoder for the final render. The ExtendScript debugger was pretty rough to use, as was walking the property arrays within After Effects to figure out how to render rectangles from MIDI data. Iâ€™ll consider alternatives. I love AE, but a good scripting interface is a must these days.

title: Sweetwater â€“ A 3D Player Piano
text:
My Code
To be fair to those who wrote the extension, itâ€™s probably not as bad as this code that drew the rectangles from the MIDI data (generated object by Tone.js). However, I havenâ€™t found a better documented way for drawing rectangles, so I may take some time to refactor this â€” itâ€™s something Iâ€™m sure other people would like to do too.
https://github.com/craigmillard/sweetwater-visuals/



MIDI rectangles drawn into AE

title: Star Wars Binary Sunset
text: Stick around for the original recording. I updated the sound on this right after Christmas of 2016. I believe it was the day before Carrie Fisher died :(

title: Santeria (Cover Song) with UA plugins
text:
This is a video of me covering Santeria by Sublime. Iâ€™m not an expert on video production, but I do know it is very important to get your llamas in frame- whether they be of the cup or stuffed variety.


I also used a UA Apollo Twin as the interface, and everything was tracked in Ableton. The video was synced and edited in Premiere.

title: My Mind (Original Song)
text: I wrote this song while I was living on Susan Butcherâ€™s Dogsled farm. I was in college at the time and living in a dry cabin, that is, a cabin without running water. I will fondly remember my days living on Trail Breaker Kennel. It was right next to the airport and I became immune to landing jet noise.

title: My Mind (Original Song)

title: Hit The Road Jack (Piano Solo)
text: The Flustered Cluckers in full force at the Alaska Capital City Brewfewst. Great time!

title: Childhood Echoes at Fish Creek
text:
A nostalgic piano piece, recorded and filmed on LingÃ­t AanÃ­ (Tlingit land). I acknowledge that Iâ€™m on the traditional, unceded territory of the LingÃ­t people, specifically the Ãakâ€™w á¸´wÃ¡an (Tlingit clan) whose stewardship of this land extends since time immemorial.


Robert Schumann titled this piece Of Strange Lands and Strange People. The name suggests mystery, but to me itâ€™s always felt the opposite: deeply familiar, even nostalgic. The melody seems to carry you back, almost to the womb. Fittingly, itâ€™s part of a collection called Scenes from Childhood. This was the very first piece of music in The Adventures of Milo and Otis, a film I grew up with. It was one of the films we owned that felt like part of our home.
That same sense of memory and change is why I chose to film here at Fish Creek and Outer Point. The Douglas development just beyond this area means it wonâ€™t stay the same for long. Public comment has already closed, but for now itâ€™s still this quiet, beautiful place. Iâ€™m glad to capture this little moment, a snapshot before the landscape shifts, paired with music that has always felt like home.
Performed, Recorded, Edited and Mixed by Craig Millard.

title: About
section: Australian Hiatus, Pandemic Repatriation, and Return to Juneau #2 (2017 â€“ Present)
text:
Australian Hiatus, Pandemic Repatriation, and Return to Juneau #2 (2017 â€“ Present)



Top 1/3 Bar: Unnamed Ween Cover Band, Bottom 2/3 Bar: The Royal Wedding Band


Craig took a long break from music while living and working in Australia from 2017 to 2020. After returning during the pandemic, he founded The Royal Wedding Band with Taylor Dallas Vidic, Tim Powers, David Elrod, and Sam Roberts. The band opened The Crystal Saloon and performed â€œhits from the 20s to the 20s.â€ They played venues across Alaska, including weddings. Additional members included Rob Cohen, Luke Weld, Chazz Gist, and Ceanne. Craig has recently joined a Ween cover band with local Juneau famouses: Simon Taylor, Jake Soboleff, Austin Osterhout, and Shona Strauser (More broadly known as: Craig Ween, Simon Ween, Jake Ween, Austin Ween, and Shona Ween)
Craig has performed at multiple Alaska Folk Festivals and Mudrooms.

title: About
section: The College Years and Return to Juneau (2011 â€“ 2017)
text:
The College Years and Return to Juneau (2011 â€“ 2017)



Top: Flustered Cluckers, Bottom: Annie Where The Sun Donâ€™t Shine


During that time he started a band with Annie B, Eli Barry-Garland, and Megan Packee called Annie Where The Sun Donâ€™t Shine. They performed at venues including the UAF Pub and The Marlin, playing Annie Bartholomewâ€™s original works and blues hits.
After returning to Juneau, Craig co-founded and named The Flustered Cluckers, a bluesy rock cover band that played Brewfest, The JACC, McGivneyâ€™s, The Rendezvous, The Rockwell, and the Juneau Maritime Festival. Founding members included Sophie Lager, Alexei Painter, Craig Millard, and Yoshi Tanha, with additional members Darren Jaeckel and Luke Weld. Craig also performed solo at McGivneyâ€™s with originals and covers.

title: About
text:
The Early Years (1990s â€“ 2005)



Craig in the All Alaska Jazz Band


Craig is a musician (piano, vocals, guitar) and producing artist residing in Juneau, Alaska. Craig began playing piano at age seven and studied with Sue Kazama throughout middle/high school. He participated in the JDHS Jazz band and was selected for the All Alaska Jazz Band directed by Bill Watrous in 2004â€“2005. The Jazz band is part of the Sitka Jazz Festival. He briefly studied music at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, where he accidentally enrolled in a 400-level history of music course, then later earned a business degree with a concentration in finance.



Craig playing pianos when he was young

title: About
text:
Production Skills
Craig is a software developer by trade and merges that with creative work in music and video. Heâ€™s especially interested in MIDI-controlled environments. One recent project included a background video for a talent portion in the Miss Gay America national pageant.

title: DRAFT: UNNAMED WEEN COVER BAND: Will knock your socks off!
text:
One day while getting my oil changed at Southeast Mine Supply I received a call about joining a â€œWeenâ€ cover band. I confess I had never heard about Ween, but the pitch was good. â€œHighly irreverant and mostly innapropriateâ€ was an immediate sell.
Flash forward to mid year and weâ€™ve done our first Gig for a private party at the Red Dog. Exciting things are coming for this band!
Iâ€™ve learned a ton by working with these musicians. Technical know-how at the musical theory and audio hardware level + talent makes for a high-production show.
In ear monitoring is a game changer and having your own custom mix makes playing SO MUCH more enjoyable, especially if you need to sit in the back of the mix and groove.

title: An End Once and For All by Clint Mansell
text: I originally recorded this on 3/1/2016, so Iâ€™ve listed that as the publish date, but I went back and hit it with some re-engineering at the sound level on 2/13/2017.

title: Hallelujah by Leonard Cohen
text: Just a solo piano cover by the great Leonard Cohen.

title: Mr.Â Blue (Cover Song)
text:
If you do ever get to talk to me about television I will probably hit you with the Bojack recommendation. I think consensus is it warms up into season two, but I actually donâ€™t mind the first season.
I think the very adult subject matter throws a lot of people off since sprinkled in are animal jokesâ€”there is a bit of dissonance between the fun puns and existentialist depression. If you watch the whole thing you might hear this song.

title: Shredderggietto (This is Bach and it Rocks)
text:
I actually got the idea of this from Tenacious Dâ€™s Pick of Destiny. A bit sloppy but whadda ya gonna do? Itâ€™s rock and roll, hunny.
Also this isnâ€™t really solo piano, but accompanied piano â€” stop being so pedantic.

title: Still Alive (Portal)
text:
I got some inspiration to try and create the effect from Portal, a.k.a. GLaDOS. Itâ€™s a lot of funâ€”there are things I could have smoothed outâ€”but Iâ€™m satisfied with this pass.
The song is Still Alive and by the great and creative Jonathan Coultonâ€”check out his website: jonathancoulton.com

title: T.N.T. Acoustic (AC/DC)
text:
Iâ€™ve never really taken guitar lessons and am terrified to see all my bad habits face me. Itâ€™s a great instrument, but except for a few songs Iâ€™m on piano. (So I say â€œI donâ€™t play guitarâ€¦ BUT I have watched a lot of Angus Young videos on YouTubeâ€ ğŸ˜‰).



Iâ€™ve liked AC/DC since I was a kid. My friend James Dawson burned me all their albums and I actually bought Stiff Upper Lip. Iâ€™ve got the â€œstudioâ€ set up.
In this clip, at the beginning thereâ€™s a little guitar lick that I play which is 100% recorded using the GoProâ€™s onboard mic. I think it sounds really full because of the sympathetic vibrations coming up the neck and through the attachment device.
I switch to a mix between the GoProâ€™s audio and the â€œstudio mixâ€ right before I start singing â€” if you listen carefully you can hear it. The â€œstudio mixâ€ is the guitar with effects coming in on a 1/4â€ via a Scarlett 2i2 USB interface. The vocals come in via that big-ass mic with an XLR connection to the Scarlett 2i2.
Guitar and singing are hard to record (at the same time) because no matter the setup, if youâ€™re using an acoustic guitar youâ€™re going to get a lot of that into the mic. The vocals donâ€™t sound as warm or full as Iâ€™d like because I had to adjust (reduce) the vocal track around the 1k to 3k range. I did that because the guitar â€œslapâ€ percussion was REALLY loud and made the whole mix basically suck green goat balls.
Anyway â€” turned out okay.
